Conference Team
session.name: Workshop - Beyond Firewalls: DevOps-Driven Application Security with ADR & Real-Time Threat Detection
session.details: In today’s fast-paced digital world, cyber threats lurk in the shadows, waiting to exploit vulnerabilities in your applications. This hands-on workshop is designed to help developers, security teams, and IT professionals understand how Application Detection & Response (ADR) can detect, report and block these threats before they cause damage.Through real-world case studies, live demos, and interactive discussions, you'll learn how ADR works, why traditional security measures fall short, and how to implement proactive defense strategies to keep your applications safe. Join us and take your application security to the next level!

session.name: Opening DevOps Transformation Day
session.details: DevOps is all about communication and collaboration throughout the delivery chain. Technology and processes are important, but you need a suitable culture to make DevOps work. But how does such a culture look, and what can be done to establish it?Opening:Ben Linders will kick off the Transformation Day exploring how you can foster a sustainable collaboration and knowledge-sharing culture that supports successful DevOps adoption in your organization

session.name: Building Trust in the Transformation Journey
session.details: Enterprise spend on Digital Transformation is forecast to reach almost $4 trillion by2027 (IDC), yet it is widely acknowledged that many of these transformations will fail. According to McKinsey 70% of digital transformation initiatives fail to meet their goals (Mckinsey-pitfalls-in-transformations). Their research found four main reasons for Failure:• set fact-based, high aspirations,• explain the ‘why’of the transformation to the organisation,• execute, focusing on the activity of change, rather than the outcome• sustain post-transformation effortThis talk shares some of the challenges encountered and solutions arrived at from the largest DevOps transformation undertaken. It will help attendee's understand how they can avoid being part of the 'failing' 70% no matter where they are in their transformation journey today.

session.name: Break
Leading Without Authority: A CTO’s Journey from Product to Services
session.details: The talk shares lessons learned moving from product firms to service organizations and back, showing why sustained credibility as a hands-on individual contributor matters more than positional power. It explains how “Trojan-horse” proof-of-concepts - small, high-impact use cases - bridge gaps between business units and turn technology into a common language with the board. Attendees will leave with practical ideas for influencing strategy, aligning metrics, and fostering cross-team collaboration while still writing code.

session.name: The sociotechnical debt of AI: breaking Conway's Third Law
session.details: Yes, the famous Conway has two other laws that we don't talk much about... and what is the link with AI and sociotechnical systems? Let's see... :-]This talk introduces the concept of "AI organizational debt", the hidden costs and constraints that emerge when organizations bolt AI capabilities onto existing team structures without considering the broader sociotechnical implications.Through a blend of academic research, practical experience, and slightly desperate humor, we'll explore how traditional enterprise architecture patterns clash with the unique demands of AI systems. You'll learn why your carefully designed team boundaries might create unexpected AI bottlenecks and how to reshape your organization to better support human and artificial intelligence. Using real-world examples, we'll examine patterns and anti-patterns in AI adoption and propose a new framework for thinking about organizational design in the age of AI.

session.name: Lunch Break

session.longAbstract:
Psychological safety is important for tech organizations as it enables faster delivery, innovation, learning from failures, and experimentation. People only dare to challenge the status quo when they feel included and safe to contribute. Then failures can become opportunities for learning and sharing ideas for improvement across the whole organization.

Learning objectives:
- Learn what psychological safety is and what it isn’t
- Recognize warning signals of low psychological safety
- See the benefits that improving psychological safety can bring
- Explore factors that foster and drive psychological safety

Agenda:
- Workshop introduction and check-in exercise
- Definitions and theory of psychological safety
- What psychological safety isn't, and what to (not) expect from it
- How psychological safety and DevOps relate to each other
- Exercise: Recognizing warning signals about lower levels of psychological safety
- The benefits that psychological safety can bring
- Exercise: Exploring factors that drive and foster psychological safety
- Dos and don'ts for leaders for establishing psychological safety.
- Wrap up, ask me anything, and takeaways
session.name: Transformation Day Workshop: Fostering a Sustainable Collaborative Culture with Psychological Safety
session.details: Many DevOps efforts struggle with developing an appropriate company culture. Psychological safety is a key enabler for an effective and sustainable organizational-wide collaborative culture. It increases personal engagement, makes it easier for people to speak up at work, and enables learning from failure. When people feel psychologically safe, your organization will become more adaptive and resilient, able to deal with changes and innovate.In this workshop, you'll learn how to foster a culture of psychological safety that enables high-performing teams to deliver faster and better. The practical exercises teach you to recognize the warning signals of low psychological safety and to take appropriate action to increase the level of psychological safety.

session.name: Break
Conference Check-in
Welcome and Opening Keynote of DevOpsCon Munich 2025
session.details: Welcome and opening remarks of DevOpsCon Munich 2025 by the Program Chair Sebastian Meyen.

session.name: How Developer Platforms Fail (And How Yours Won’t)
session.details: Platform engineering promises so much, from developer productivity to better operational efficiency, and yet the Trough of Disillusionment still beckons. "Over promised, over sold and over here", if you're in a company of more than 50 people and growing you're almost guaranteed to have creating a platform to help you scale safely and cost-effectively. But how do you doge the disillusionment and develop what delivers?In this entertaining and thoughtful keynote, Russ Miles (Developer, Listener, Author and Builder of platforms) will unpack the myths around platform engineering. Touring a collection of real-world examples where platforms swim or sink through the lense of philosophy, Russ will explore the many choices you can make that will make the difference between a successful platform that your teams will love and a franken-platform that no one wants to touch.Together we'll explore which myths hold and which fold under scrutiny so that you have the best possible chance of building a loved internal developer platform. Why? Because your developers are worth it(TM).

session.name: Break
Platform Engineering Beyond Build-vs-Buy: The MinIO Case Study
session.details: This talk traces the life cycle of an S3-compatible storage service inside a software-services company. We first built and ran MinIO in-house, packaging it as an internal “as-a-service” offer and sharpening our object-storage expertise. Later, deeper functional and compliance demands pushed us to adopt an external enterprise platform. The journey illustrates how platform engineering drives consolidation—uniform APIs, single governance model, consistent developer experience—regardless of whether the underlying solution is built or bought. We distill evaluation criteria, operational trade-offs, and the product-mindset practices that kept the transition predictable and the platform clear of lock-in.

session.name: Mastering Kubernetes Autoscaling for AI and Real-Time Traffic
session.details: Autoscaling Kubernetes for real-time traffic, complex workloads, and AI/LLM applications introduces unique performance and scalability challenges. This session focuses on practical methods to scale efficiently for latency-sensitive scenarios and resource-intensive AI-driven tasks. We’ll explore Kubernetes Event-Driven Autoscaling (KEDA) strategies tailored specifically for dynamic real-time traffic, custom metrics for AI workloads, and considerations for managing complex services. Additionally, we’ll address the trade-offs involved, pitfalls to avoid, and illustrate best practices through real-world examples. Join us for an insightful look at building robust autoscaling strategies optimized for real-time responsiveness, AI efficiency, and cost control in Kubernetes.

session.name: Real‑World DevOps Attacks: Breaches from Push to Prod
session.details: Your automation pipeline safeguards the crown jewels of the business—source code, secrets, release keys—yet the very workflows meant to accelerate delivery can be leveraged against you. Attackers now aim for build scripts, workflow actions, container tags, and infrastructure templates to slip tainted components straight into production without tripping a single test.This keynote is a guided walk‑through of several real‑world, headline‑making DevOps incidents. We’ll trace how each break‑in unfolded, pinpoint the pipeline stages that provided the attacker’s leverage, and unpack the common blind spots that let them succeed. Then we flip the perspective to show what teams did next and what mindsets keep pipelines safe without throttling velocity.You’ll leave with a clear picture of the modern DevOps attack surface—from commit to deploy—and a concise set of questions to ask your own pipeline on Monday morning: Where are my crown jewels stored? How hard are they to reach? Whether you build, test, or operate, this talk arms you to ship fast and safe.

session.name: Streamlining CI/CD: Unlocking the Power of Metadata for Scalable Pipelines
session.details: Managing CI/CD pipelines across complex environments doesn’t have to feel like a juggling act. This talk explores how metadata can drive optimized and scalable pipelines, enhanced observability, and streamlined deployment processes.By integrating reusable workflows, centralized configurations, and efficient environment promotion strategies, we’ll address challenges like scaling multi-tenant architectures, managing white-label deployments, and maintaining robust security practices. We’ll also discuss controlling agnostic workload management to ensure pipelines remain flexible and adaptable across diverse architectures.Attendees will learn how metadata and traits files fuel automation, traceability, and collaboration, with practical insights into GitHub Actions, manifest-driven deployments, and external integrations.Whether you’re tackling multi-environment promotion or simplifying approval workflows, this session offers actionable strategies for scaling pipelines with efficiency.

session.name: The Great Security Splits: Replacing Pain with Joy in the Middle
session.details: Developers shift left. Security shifts right. And in the middle? That’s where things get painful. As teams pull in opposite directions - using vastly different tools - AppSec can feel like doing the splits. Workflows get stretched to their limit, innovation slows, and frustration builds where it hurts the most.But what if security didn’t have to be a source of strain? What if we could flex, adapt, and create a way of working that sparks joy instead of friction? Because let’s be honest: running with a high heel on one foot and a sneaker on the other won’t get you far.In this talk, Paul shares personal stories of struggle, growth, and the search for better ways of working - because security shouldn’t come at the cost of happiness. We’ll explore how to remove the pain points of AppSec, build more satisfying workflows, and reclaim your right to enjoy the work you do every day. The best security isn’t just strong - it’s seamless, supportive, and even fun.Let’s find a better way together.

session.name: Securing the Speed of Innovation: How AI-Driven Development and Security Drive Success
session.details: In today’s fast-paced software environments, development speed and security can no longer exist in isolation. AI is transforming how code is written, reviewed, and deployed—turning traditional bottlenecks into opportunities for innovation. Yet this acceleration also introduces new challenges around reliability, compliance, and exposure to risk. This session explores how AI-driven development and security teams can effectively collaborate to secure innovation without slowing delivery. Drawing from real-world DevSecOps practices, we’ll discuss how AI can help detect vulnerabilities earlier, reduce incident response times, and improve the overall resilience of software pipelines. Key questions include: • How does AI change the role of code review?• What liabilities arise from AI-generated code?• And how can organizations ensure AI remains a sustainable enabler rather than a new source of risk?

session.name: Break
A Brief History of Engineering
session.details: From the pioneering trailblazers of mainframe computing and space exploration to the rockstars who unleashed the internet and cloud revolution— and now to the emergent Artificial Engineers redefining our digital landscape, software engineering has continuously evolved through cycles of abstraction, automation, and transformation.This talk traces the key technologies, methodologies, and cultural shifts that have driven each era of innovation. We’ll explore how successive layers of abstraction have unlocked extraordinary digital capabilities, even as they have introduced new complexities and cognitive challenges. Today, as AI evolves from a supportive copilot to an autonomous agent capable of digital manifestation, we stand at a pivotal crossroads. Here, the principles of human ingenuity, machine intelligence, and sustainable engineering must converge.How can we navigate this seismic shift while ensuring reliability, security, and ethical governance? Which timeless lessons from our past must we preserve to prevent innovation from spiraling into chaos? By weaving together historical analysis, technical insights, and strategic foresight, this talk provides a comprehensive roadmap for understanding our engineering heritage and steering its future evolution. Join me as we chart the journey from yesterday’s breakthroughs to tomorrow’s boundless possibilities.

session.name: GPUs on Kubernetes Unlocked
session.details: Kubernetes speaks CPU and memory out-of-the-box, but large-language-model workloads live or die by GPUs. We start by framing the gap: until the control-plane knows what accelerators exist on each node, the scheduler can’t place Pods intelligently. Node Feature Discovery, extended with GPU awareness, gives Kubernetes that vocabulary, attaching labels for architecture, memory and sharing mode. The device-plugin framework then turns each accelerator—or fraction of one—into a schedulable resource, while the GPU Operator keeps drivers, runtimes and metrics aligned so clusters stay declarative. Dynamic Resource Allocation lifts the abstraction another step by letting workloads request a “high-memory GPU” and leaving the exact match to the scheduler. Why bother? Model size and latency targets dictate very different layouts. Some deployments thrive when several GPUs cooperate inside a single server; others must stretch across nodes when no box is big enough. At the opposite end of the scale, time-slicing and Multi-Instance GPU let lighter tasks share silicon safely, squeezing more value from every watt. By the end you’ll understand how discovery, allocation and sharing fit together and where to start when your next tuning run or inference service demands more accelerator muscle than Kubernetes exposes today.

session.name: Resilience From Verifiable Trust: How the Bill of Behavior (BoB) Achieves Supply Chain Security and Removes Toil From the End-User
session.details: Regulations usually create effort and toil, but leave companies with questionable improvements on their actual security exposure: We introduce the “Bill of Behavior” (BoB): A vendor-supplied profile detailing known benign runtime behaviors for software, designed to be distributed directly within OCI artifacts. Generated using eBPF, a BoB codifies expected syscalls, file access patterns, network communications, and capabilities. This empowers powerful, signature-less anomaly detection, allowing end-users to infer malicious activity or tampering in third-party software without the current burden of authoring and maintaining complex, custom security rules. We will demonstrate the BoB specification's portability across diverse ecosystems, languages, and stacks. The main focus of our talk will be on emphasizing the vital role of user transparency and user experience in creating security implementations based on what we -the community- already have and know. Our goal is to strengthen Cyber Resilience by interpreting the EU CRA and EU NIS regulations into a meaningful technology implementation and thus empower EVERY cloud native practitioner with a shareable, composable, and actionable framework for runtime security, that requires minimal friction to adopt.... and that actually works.

session.name: Streamlining Developer Support: Integrating ChatGPT into CI/CD Pipelines
session.details: Integrating ChatGPT into CI/CD pipelines enhances developer support by automating routine tasks, providing instant troubleshooting, and offering real-time code reviews. Its natural language processing capabilities allow it to respond to developer queries effectively. In this session, I will present a case study demonstrating our implementation of ChatGPT to solve complex microservices CI/CD environment support issues, thereby providing clearer assistance to our developers.

session.name: The AI Code War: When Generative AI Meets Generative Malware
session.details: We are in an AI Code War. While generative AI accelerates development, attackers match this speed with their own models to automate exploits. This velocity creates two critical challenges: AI writing inherently vulnerable code and “secure” code decaying faster than any human patching cycle can manage. This rapid decay creates invisible attack paths that traditional security pipelines cannot detect. In this talk, we will demonstrate how AI can write vulnerable code in seconds, how attackers use AI to identify and exploit those weaknesses just as fast, and introduce Vibe Security — an emerging discipline focused on defending code as it evolves, not just scanning artifacts once they are produced. Attendees will learn how to detect, visualize, and secure the unpredictable code that AI now writes at scale. If development accelerates, security must accelerate too — otherwise, the attacker wins by default.

session.name: Stories from the road of building a secure bare-metal infrastructure
session.details: Did you know that kubernetes is a great entry point for running bare-metal clusters hosting virtual cloud infrastructure? But now imagine all of this needs to satisfy the highest standards of security. That involves a fully air-gapped installation, network isolation, tenant isolation.In this talk you will listen to some stories of a huge development project of such a infrastructure. It will cover general concepts, best-practice for known tools in the kubernetes ecosystem (ArgoCD, Prometheus, Loki, etc.), usage and development of operators and more.

session.name: Lunch Break
Walking the path: addressing real-world threats with Application Detection and Response (ADR)
session.details: An effective application security program focuses on applying the right tools and processes at the right moment. But you will need to rethink your security strategy beyond shift-left practices; while identifying and fixing vulnerabilities early in development before deploying to production is essential, it is simply not enough.The reality is that vulnerabilities inevitably make it into production. Many security programs overlook how to deal with attacks against the vulnerabilities that were missed. Application Detection and Response (ADR) fills this critical gap by providing real-time visibility into running applications and the ability to block attacks on application vulnerabilities in your production applications.

session.name: Break
The One About Titanic and Metrics, or Why Jack Fit on the Log
session.details: This talk covers the cardinality of metrics in Kubernetes clusters. We will explore what cardinality is, why it is important in the context of observability, and how to manage it efficiently in a Kubernetes environment.We will cover: What is Cardinality?Its importance in KubernetesCommon Challenges:Time Series Explosion Storage and Performance CostStrategies for Managing Cardinality: Labeling Prudently Adjusting Scraping and Retention Using Aggregation ToolsManaging the cardinality of metrics is crucial to maintaining an efficient and scalable monitoring system in Kubernetes. By adopting good practices in metric labeling and using appropriate tools, we can ensure that our monitoring system remains robust and cost-effective.

session.name: Secure by Design: Kubernetes the Hard Way in 45 Minutes
session.details: Kubernetes is powerful — but when abstracted behind managed platforms, critical operational knowledge is often lost. This session revisits the raw essentials: building a secure Kubernetes cluster from scratch in just 45 minutes, step by step, without relying on installers or automation tools. Along the way, DevSecOps principles are embedded into every layer — from provisioning hardened Linux nodes to securing the control plane and implementing a zero trust networking model. Participants will develop a clear understanding of Kubernetes core components, their interactions, plugin points, and runtime architecture. You’ll gain deep insights into TLS bootstrapping, etcd security, RBAC configuration, API auditing, and network policy enforcement with Cilium — all in an environment you build and control yourself. Rather than rely on opaque defaults, we’ll explore how to make intentional security decisions across the entire stack, aligned with real-world threat models and compliance needs. This session not only demystifies the inner workings of Kubernetes but also empowers engineers to embed security directly into the infrastructure they operate. Whether you’re preparing for production readiness, building a home lab, or simply seeking to understand what your platform does under the hood — this is Kubernetes the DevSecOps way: deliberate, transparent, and resilient by design.

session.name: Terraform from the Ground Up
session.details: Are you new to Terraform and/or Infrastructure as Code? No worries, this talk will ramp up your knowledge. This talk will answer the following questions:What is Terraform? Is Terraform free to use, what do I need to be aware of?Why should I prefer Terraform in contrast to other Infrastructure as Code tools?* How do I get started, which prerequisites do I need?What are the fundamentals of Terraform?How do I write a Terraform configuration?How does a "Terraform flow" look like, to provision resources (live demonstration)* Where do I find best practices and style guides?In addition, I'll also explain how to integrate the provisioning, management and destruction of resources using Terraform in CI/CD.

session.name: Lessons from 10 years of Platform Engineering
session.details: Platform Engineering is the new hype on the block. But we've been doing this for some 10 years, we just didn't call it Platform Engineering. We provided self service enabled platforms with guardrails for development teams to consume. Some did successfully, some didn't ... This talk will help you learn from the mistakes we made along the road and but also from the successes. Spoiler: it's mostly about communication.

session.name: Rise of the Machines
session.details: Modern attackers now operate at machine speed, powered by AI systems that independently scan, adapt, and execute complex attack chains across cloud environments. These autonomous agents can exploit CI/CD pipelines, pivot through workloads, and weaponize misconfigurations in seconds. The result is a threat landscape where cloud and CI/CD environments can be breached in seconds. In this session, Marcel breaks down how agentic AI is transforming both sides of the cybersecurity battlefield. He reveals why runtime protection has become essential — and how defenders can finally fight back by deploying their own agentic AI systems. These defensive agents can continuously monitor runtime activity, correlate signals, respond autonomously, and out-pace human-driven SOC workflows. Instead of reacting to threats, agentic AI helps organizations predict, prevent, and contain attacks before they escalate. The next wave of threats is evolving autonomously. Your defenses need to keep pace.

session.name: Break
From Pi to Cluster: A Tale of Clusters and Chaos
session.details: Admittedly, everyone working with Kubernetes has thought about it at some point: Building their own cluster with their own hardware. But let’s face it, most people stop at the thought, right? Now, imagine mixing a career changer with a few months of Kubernetes know-how and three Raspberry Pis gifted for their birthday. What could possibly go wrong? (Spoiler: A lot ;)) In my talk, I’ll walk you through the ups and downs of my Raspberry Pi cluster adventure - From initial setup struggles over hacking my way through networking quirks to the sweet moment when "kubectl get nodes" actually works (eventually). If you’ve ever thought, “Hey, I should totally build my own cluster,” or if you're just curious to see what happens when someone actually does, join me. You’ll probably laugh, maybe cry, and definitely learn something.

session.name: Continuous Compliance: Automation Pipelines in Regulated Financial Services
session.details: In this session, we’ll explore strategies for safely upgrading IaaS, SaaS, and other mission-critical back-end services within the stringent controls of financial regulation. We’ll examine how to balance the imperative to patch security vulnerabilities and resolve system inconsistencies against the risk that infrastructure changes may alter key calculation outputs; potentially triggering regulatory review and preserving audit trails and change controls. We introduce a “dual-run” strategy, where new and legacy environments operate in parallel to validate outputs, alongside comprehensive documentation and risk-assessment playbooks. Finally, we'll discuss how to reconcile mandatory security patches and configuration fixes with regulatory demands for stability in reported figures by using automation pipelines and AI-driven monitoring. At the end of the talk, you’ll have a concrete road map for implementing secure, compliant upgrades to ensure every infrastructure modification is fully justified, traceable, and compliant by combining impact analysis, stakeholder sign-off workflows, and evidence-driven reporting.

session.name: Bow for me, for I am coroot
session.details: Every once in a while, an hashtag#opensource tool comes along that absolutely blows you away.For Kris Buytaert, hashtag#Coroot is one of those game-changers!He is thrilled to share his experiences with Coroot, an #eBPF-based #observability tool that’s shaping up to be a formidable tool in your monitoring ecosystem. Licensed under Apache 2.0, Coroot integrates seamlessly into any ecosystem, making it a versatile solution for your security and performance challenges.

session.name: Tackling DevEx Imposter Syndrome or how to evolve your DevOps through Platform Engineering
session.details: DevOps teams are often perceived as a necessary cost for critical operations. Increasingly, they’re being rebranded as DevEx, with expanded responsibilities but little clarity around goals or strategy. This leaves engineers feeling confused amd even more disconnected from product development and company objectives. The answer lies in fully embracing platform engineering; a transformation that empowers DevOps to operate with the purpose and impact of Product. This shift is an opportunity to break away from the outdated “sysadmins keeping the lights on” mindset and redefine their role as strategic enablers.I’ll share how Birdie, a healthtech scale-up, reimagined its DevOps function by adopting platform engineering principles. I’ll explore how this approach enables DevOps engineers to think like product engineers- leveraging design, strategy, and user-focused practices - whilst valuing their core expertise.Attendees will gain actionable insights into aligning people, processes, and technology to foster collaboration, build a strategy and avoid common pitfalls!

session.name: Preparing for the quantum leap: What post-quantum cryptography means for devs
session.details: As quantum computing evolves from theory to reality, the cryptographic foundations of today's digital infrastructure are under threat. Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) aims to secure data against future quantum attacks, but the shift will not be seamless. This talk explores how the transition to PQC will affect developers—from libraries and APIs to key sizes, performance trade-offs, and integration challenges. We'll demystify NIST's PQC standardization efforts, examine real-world implications of deploying quantum-resistant algorithms, and outline what developers can do now to future-proof their applications. Whether you're working on secure communications, embedded systems, or cloud services, understanding PQC is critical. This is not just a cryptography problem—it’s a software engineering challenge.

session.name: # Leverage K8s-Knowhow by Demystifying Containers – #DeepDive
session.details: You use containers every day — directly or indirectly.Docker, LXC, Incus, systemd-nspawn, Podman… or inside Kubernetes, Nomad, or Docker Swarm.But what is a container?This is a #slideless live deep dive.We open a terminal (and a drawing board) and reconstruct:docker container run -v /file:/srv -ti ubuntuEntirely from scratch, just using the shell.Along the way, we explore and experience the Linux kernel features that actually make containers:Namespacescgroupschroot / pivot_rootOverlayFSbind-mountsnetworking primitivesAfter understanding containers at the Linux level, we connect the dots back to KubernetesThis talk is fast-paced and hands-on.

session.name: Break
Code as Leadership: Embedding Agile Excellence in DevOps Teams
session.details: If leadership stays in the backlog, quality won't reach production. This talk explores how tech-leads can embed excellence through concrete coding disciplines: enforceable standards (via TDD, linters), review pipelines, and regular refactoring. We’ll connect cultural intent with technical execution, showing how Agile leadership anchored in code practices enables teams to deliver with confidence and cohesion.

session.name: Lifting Large Language Models on Kubernetes
session.details: Large language models now ship in double-digit gigabytes, and Kubernetes feels every byte. Each scale-out or restart waits while weights stream across the network and into local storage; the copy alone can dwarf the actual server boot time genai-k8s. This talk surveys the options for transferring those weights to a node without waiting forever. We compare the classic init-container copy pattern, KServe’s Modelcar sidecar that sidesteps the copy with a symbolic link genai-k8s, packaging weights as passive OCI data images that travel through your existing registries, and the brand-new ImageVolume source that mounts an OCI image directly when the 1.31 feature gate is enabled. For each strategy, you will see its speed, operational overhead, and cluster prerequisites. We conclude with a straightforward decision checklist: when your SLA requires the absolute fastest spin-up, when a single shared cache is sufficient, and when staying on stable features outweighs raw performance. Walk away knowing which loading path to test first in your own cluster.

session.name: Inclusive Security
session.details: Inclusion ensures that diverse perspectives are considered, leading to products that cater to a broader audience and meet the needs of all users. By engaging with underrepresented groups during design and testing, and fostering a culture of collaboration, we can create more accessible and user-friendly applications. Simultaneously, security must be woven into every stage of the SDLC. Adopting a security-first mindset allows teams to identify potential vulnerabilities early, implement best practices for data protection, and ensure compliance with regulations. Regular security assessments and training are essential for maintaining a strong security posture throughout the product's lifecycle.

session.name: Monkey Business for Serious Systems: Why Chaos Engineering Isn’t Crazy, Featuring LitmusChaos
session.details: In a world where uptime is king and failure is inevitable, the smartest teams break things on purpose. Chaos Engineering, once seen as risky experimentation, has emerged as a proven method for building truly resilient systems. In this talk, we explore how controlled chaos can uncover hidden weaknesses and bolster confidence in production environments, without actually breaking them.Join me as I dive into the “monkey business” behind Chaos Engineering and demonstrate how it brings real value to serious, mission-critical systems. Using LitmusChaos, the CNCF incubating project, we’ll walk through real-world use cases, patterns, and pitfalls of implementing chaos in cloud-native environments. From injecting faults to observing system behavior and defining steady states, we’ll cover how to build a chaos-first culture that aligns with SRE, DevOps, and platform engineering goals.Key Takeaways: 1. Understanding Chaos Engineering: Learn how to proactively identify and address system weaknesses using controlled experiments.2. Tool Demonstration: See how LitmusChaos enables simplified chaos experiments with real-world examples.3. Cultural Impact: Understand how Chaos Engineering promotes collaboration, continuous learning, and a focus on reliability.

session.name: Fine-Grained Access Control (FGA) in Focus - Live Hacking and Best Practices for Developers
session.details: Many developers rely on traditional role-based access control (RBAC) in their applications. However,in modern system architectures, RBAC often reaches its limits. Dynamic permissions, contextualdependencies, and multi-tenant environments require a more precise and adaptable access model.Fine-Grained Access Control (FGA) delivers exactly that — enabling highly tailored, context-awareauthorization logic that integrates seamlessly with microservices, cloud platforms, and scalablearchitectures .But how can these concepts be put into practice?In this talk, the speaker will walk through real-world use cases to show how organizations canenhance their security architecture using FGA. A live hacking session will illustrate the vulnerabilitiesof traditional access control approaches and demonstrate common attack vectors.Participants will then explore a best-practice implementation that highlights how FGA can besuccessfully integrated into existing systems. This session is tailored for developers and security professionals seeking to deepen their knowledgeof modern access control strategies through practical, real-life examples.

session.name: Securing the SDLC: From Container Images to AI Agents
session.details: This presentation examines the evolution of supply chain security challenges from container images to AI agents. We'll explore how modern development practices create new attack vectors, from containers running hundreds of unnecessary packages to AI agents accessing enterprise systems without proper security controls. The session demonstrates solutions like hardened images that dramatically reduce attack surfaces and examines emerging Model Context Protocol vulnerabilities. Through analysis of real incidents and threat patterns, we'll show how to apply container best practice, to build secure AI-enhanced development environments before attacks spread.

session.name: Meet & Mingle: Networking Break
DevOpsCon Exchange (ON-SITE ONLY)
session.details: One of the key principles of DevOps is based on sharing knowledge and experience. There's no better place to do that than at a conference where so many DevOps professionals meet! Come along and discuss the topics that matter most to you with a group of passionate, like-minded people.We’re setting up three special discussion tables, spotlighting the topics Kubernetes, Platform Engineering, and Business & Company Culture to spark conversation and connection after a full day of learning. Whether you want to trade tips on container orchestration, swap ideas on building better internal platforms, or discuss how people make DevOps happen, including culture and leadership, there’s a place for you. Pull up a chair, share your experiences, and enjoy some great conversations with fellow DevOps enthusiasts.

session.name: Conference Check-in
Internal Developer Platform Day 2 Operations Solved
session.details: In most cases, if we work very, very, hard, we could enable developers to create something meaningful. Most of us do that by creating abstractions. Instead of forcing developers to spend years trying to understand the intricacies of Kubernetes, we create Helm charts that enable developers to modify a simple YAML values file and apply charts to the cluster. If we are advanced, we create CRDs and controllers that result in even better abstractions and start resembling services that developers can consume. We progress further from there by creating services not only for applications but also for databases, clusters, or anything else. We platform engineers, become service providers, and developers start consuming those services. Here's the problem though, all that tends to help only with day 1 operations. Developers can create or update something in a very easy way, but when it comes to operating and observing that something, they often end up being equally confused as they were before. Our services do not show the information they need, so they need to dig deeper into lower-level resources to find out what's going on. That negates some of the main reasons we started offering them services. That's horrible. We're building something that looks useful when someone starts using it, and it turns useless afterwards.In this talk, we tackle a major challenge in Internal Developer Platforms built on top of Kubernetes: enabling developers to not only manage their applications and infrastructure but also to observe and troubleshoot them effectively. We will demonstrate how to propagate meaningful status information to top-level resources. That will solve real-world issues by making day 2 operations easier for developers without overwhelming them with low-level details. We'll learn how to create custom resource definitions (CRDs) and controllers that simplify the developer experience and propagate relevant information up the hierarchy tree.

session.name: Break
QUIC and HTTP/3: The Next Step in Web Security and Performance
session.details: In recent years, the ways that we can deliver HTTP has improved in occasional leaps, from 1.0, 1.1, a big step to 2.0, and now 3.0. One of the biggest obstacles has been TCP, which isn't a great fit for HTTP, but we are stuck with it – or are we? QUIC is a reimagining of TCP that runs over "the other protocol", UDP, and integrates TLS 1.3, giving us a step up in performance and security. Discover how it works, how you can configure your servers and applications, deploy and test it today.

session.name: Terraform and GitHub: Infrastructure as Code meets GitHub Automation and Collaboration
session.details: You’ve taken your first steps with Terraform—you understand the concepts and how to provision and destroy cloud resources using its commands. Now you’re wondering: how can Terraform workflows be automated with GitHub? What do automated processes look like, what should you keep in mind when designing Terraform configurations for team collaboration, and how can you enforce best practices for code changes?Then don’t miss this session! I’ll demonstrate a complete GitHub Flow for managing code changes in a Terraform configuration and discuss best practices in detail. Perfect for anyone looking to level up their experience with Terraform and GitHub and kickstart more collaborative, automated workflows.

session.name: Beyond CI/CD: Building Developer Platforms That Scale DevOps
session.details: DevOps isn’t just about tools—it’s about empowering developers with the right platforms and workflows. As organizations grow, ad-hoc scripts and pipeline sprawl no longer cut it. The future of DevOps lies in platform engineering: reusable, standardized, and developer-friendly systems that abstract complexity without killing flexibility. In this talk, we’ll explore how to move from scattered DevOps practices to a cohesive internal developer platform (IDP). You’ll learn how to think in terms of golden paths, self-service infrastructure, policy-as-code, and GitOps workflows. We’ll also dive into lessons learned from real-world platform teams: balancing guardrails with autonomy, reducing cognitive load, and creating feedback loops that actually improve developer experience. Whether you’re a DevOps engineer, SRE, or platform lead, this session will help you rethink DevOps not as a bottleneck—but as a scalable product your developers will love to use.

session.name: Gateway, Gateway, Gateway - What and For What?
session.details: The term "gateway" is used in the cloud environment for many different concepts: API Gateway, Ingress Gateway (Istio), and Kubernetes Gateway API (Kubernetes sig - special interest groups). All three terms have one thing in common. They create orderly and therefore controlled access to APIs. In addition to or in competition with this, the so-called ingress also (still) exists, with its associated ingress controller. With such an extensive selection of options, it is not easy to keep track of things. What is what and which "gateway" do we need in our environment? Is a single "gateway" enough for us or do we have to combine several "gateways"? How do we ensure that we don't ride the wrong horse in the future? In order to be able to assess these questions better, the different gateway concepts will be presented in this session and, as far as possible, differentiated from each other. The possible areas of application for the gateways and the coexistence of several gateways, if this makes sense, are also discussed. At the end of the session, a look into the crystal ball will attempt to clear the fog of future developments in this area.

session.name: Break
Secure your APIs: JWT or mTLS or both?
session.details: Authorized access to an API should be checked on the basis of cryptographically secured identities. This is the only way to clearly and securely identify the caller, which in turn forms the basis for an authorization check within the API. This creates the basis for robust and secure API communication.JSON Web Token (JWT) or mutual TLS (mTLS) are available for this purpose. However, a combination of both technologies can also be useful. It is important to understand the basic purposes for which JWT (authentication) and mTLS (secure and verified communication) are suitable.After an explanation of the two technologies and their associated areas of application, the respective requirements as well as advantages and disadvantages are weighed up against each other. The synergy of JWT and mTLS will also be explained and analysed in detail. The aim of the session is to be able to better assess the sensible use of one of the two technologies or a mix of both for reaching a higher level of API security.

session.name: Finding your way into a Kubernetes container for debugging
session.details: Have you ever found yourself struggling with debugging your complex Kubernetes system? Do you rely on external tools and third-party software to find what's going on inside your pods? Kubernetes debugging can be very challenging, especially in cases when container images are strictly limited in their capabilities and tools. This talk will offer a look at how to get inside a container without any special tools or additional plugins installed in Kubernetes. We will explore some of the mechanisms that containers are built around and demonstrate how to successfully connect to an application process, monitor the resources being consumed, and understand what's going on.

session.name: Zero to Hero: Turning Internal Developer Platforms into Real Products
session.details: As engineering teams grow, so does the sprawl, tools, pipelines, environments, and cognitive load. The answer? An internal developer platform. But building one that developers actually want to use is far harder than spinning up a Kubernetes cluster and slapping a UI on top.In this session, I’ll share the journey of how we built and scaled an internal developer platform called Circuit, treating it not as infrastructure, but as a product. From early MVPs to company-wide adoption across 150+ engineers, we focused on delivering real value, reducing friction, and enabling self-service without losing control.What you’ll learn:* Why internal platforms fail when they’re built like tools, not products* How to drive adoption across diverse teams through empathy, not enforcement* Building feedback loops, golden paths, and onboarding flows that scale* Defining KPIs for developer experience (yes, you can measure it)* Real-world architecture: how we stitched together GitOps, ArgoCD, Terraform, observability, and security* Mistakes we made along the way, and how we fixed themWhether you're starting your platform journey or scaling one to the next level, this talk offers practical insights into building an internal platform that developers love and SREs can trust.

session.name: OTel Legends: Build, Break, and Bend Your Collector!
session.details: Take control! In this high-velocity workshop, you’ll bend the OpenTelemetry Collector to your will — locally. Start from scratch, hack your YAMLs, zap noisy data, and reroute your metrics like a pro. No vendor strings, no limits —just pure, hands-on observability power.Grab your keyboard and get ready to break stuff (in the best way)!

session.name: Scaling Cybersecurity Training Through Automated Exercise Generation
session.details: Cybersecurity exercises are essential for preparing organizations to handle modern cyber threats, yet their creation remains slow, complex, and prohibitively expensive. This talk presents recent research and applied development by CyberArrange Security Solutions on automating the generation of cyber-range environments and training scenarios using large language models. Building on advances in reasoning-capable LLMs, we demonstrate how end-to-end automation, from environment provisioning to vulnerability implementation and scenario testing, can drastically reduce the time, expertise, and cost required to produce high-quality cyber exercises.We showcase results from our LLM development and evaluation pipeline, discuss practical performance considerations, and present a fully generated demo scenario illustrating automated reconnaissance, exploitation, privilege escalation, and social-engineering steps. The talk also highlights broader research directions: security for SMEs, critical-infrastructure protection, and the role of digital sovereignty in shaping Europe’s cybersecurity capability.

session.name: Lunch Break
DevSecOps in the age of Generative AI
session.details: DevSecOps has transformed the software development landscape by emphasizing the importance of security throughout the Secure-SDLC lifecycle. By embracing DevSecOps principles and leveraging the power of AI and GenAI, organizations can deliver secure, reliable, and high-quality software that meets the demands of the ever-evolving digital world. The era of GenAI in DevSecOps is filled with both immense opportunities and significant risks. Organizations are now focusing on developing explainable AI models, implementing ethical AI governance, and conducting adversarial testing. The evolution of DevSecOps in the AI age reflects a shift towards more proactive, automated, and intelligent cyber security practices.

session.name: Break
Tell me why I don't like ArgoCD
session.details: This isn't a session to sing praises about Argo CD—far from it. Instead, it's a space where I’ll share my frustrations as an operator who has been forced to use it. If you're interested in hearing an honest (and likely rant-filled) perspective on the challenges and pain points of working with Argo CD. Feel free to join.

session.name: Product Thinking 101 for Platform Engineers
session.details: Want to level up your engineering career? Product management and ownership skills will help you showcase the business value of IT investments and align technical solutions with company goals. Learn how modern engineering teams—regardless of size or industry—can thrive by adopting a product thinking mindset. Stéphane is a Platform Engineer applying product thinking, who will give you actionable insights from his journey at DKB. You'll discover how embracing product management principles can help your team deliver more impactful results and gain greater ownership of what you build.What you'll learn:How to use product discovery techniques to better understand user needs- Which metrics matter most when measuring product success- Practical frameworks for identifying real problems before jumping to solutionsTips for bringing product thinking to your engineering role

session.name: Magical Client-Side Logging – the Little Headers That Could
session.details: In a server side app, it's easy to find out what went wrong from logs. But what about the client side? How will you know when your CDN's DNS goes down, XSS is trying to steal data, or users in Belgium are unable to load your images? The W3C's Reporting API, Content-Security-Policy, Network Error Logging (NEL), and Reporting-Endpoints HTTP headers can let you know about all kinds of client-side issues that you'd otherwise never see. These browser features are new and evolving, making implementation a little tricky, so we will confront those issues and overcome them. Find out how to use them, and solve all the issues that only your customers have been seeing!

session.name: Fixing the Most Hated Task: Software Documentation in the DevOps Era
session.details: Software documentation is important, but almost no one likes to do it. Many of us have probably had some bad experiences with documentation in the past and thus want to avoid it completely. However, increasingly complex systems – including DevOps – demand a stronger reliance on well-structured documentation.This talk explores why documentation in the DevOps era is more critical than ever for developers, DevOps engineers, product owners, and all kinds of managers. We will empathize with the excuses (which you will all identify with) and the reasons (which might surprise you). We will gain insights from the history of software documentation and its current, promising trends. We will tackle typical challenges and their established solutions. We will explore the role of reverse engineering and whether AI can assist is us with that. But most importantly, we will see documentation as something that helps us, the company, and especially all the developers and engineers who come after us.This talk will help the audience:Clear up common misconceptions about software documentationDispel typical excuses and uncover undeniable reasons for doing itGet the documentation basics straightGet introduced to lightweight markup languages and their benefitsExplore the concept of docs as code and how it integrates with modern workflowsDiscover the awesomeness of diagrams as codeLearn the three ingredients for successful software documentation

session.name: Break
Mastering Kubernetes Operators: From Concept to Custom Controllers
session.details: In the rapidly evolving world of cloud-native applications, Kubernetes Operators have emerged as a powerful tool to extend the Kubernetes API and automate complex application lifecycles. This session will dive into the practical aspects of building your own Kubernetes Operator from scratch. We’ll explore the core concepts, walk through real-world examples, and highlight best practices to ensure your Operators are robust and maintainable. Whether you're a seasoned Kubernetes user or just getting started, you'll leave with the knowledge and confidence to start developing custom Operators tailored to your needs.

session.name: Why Your Code Is Clean but Your Communication Is a Mess
session.details: Imagine you’re in the middle of a sprint refinement session, and suddenly, a heated debate erupts over a user story. The Product Owner wants a feature “as fast as possible,” the team insists on “as stable as necessary,” and the deadline laughs ominously in the background. Now, multiply this by multiple teams working on the same product – chaos mode is activated. Sounds familiar?Negotiation is an everyday skill– we just call it differently: prioritization, estimation, and alignment. But too often, these conversations feel like verbal endurance tests rather than productive discussions. Time to bring the Harvard Negotiation Principle into the play: a method that helps you stay firm on the issue while staying respectful to people.In this talk, you’ll learn why great negotiations aren’t about compromise but about smart solutions that move everyone forward. You'll discover how to:- Identify interests instead of clashing over positions (Why does the PO want it now?)- Find win-win solutions instead of getting stuck in endless debates- Communicate clearly without being seen as "difficult"- De-escalate conflicts without simply giving inWith real-world examples and practical insights, this session will help you turn frustrating meetings into productive problem-solving – and finally fix those endless discussions for good!

session.name: Conference Check-in

session.workshopRequirements:
Target Group:
Developers, architects and security engineers who have high security requirements for their microservices in Kubernetes clusters. Experience with Kubernetes is helpful.
session.longAbstract:
The starting point is the TLS/mTLS termination in the ingress gateway. From then on, all further communication within the service mesh is secured using mTLS. Outgoing communication is also checked and controlled with the help of the egress gateway. In addition, it is shown which request-based authorization checks can be taken over by the service mesh.

The associated security best practices are listed and explained for each sub-aspect. Since faulty security settings can have fatal consequences, the options available for error analysis are shown for each security aspect.

Agenda:

I. Fundamentals

  • Introduction to Service Mesh and Istio Ambient
  • Benefits of Istio Ambient compared to Istio (classic)
  • Istio Ambient and Zero-Trust

II. Ingress Gateway with TLS and mTLS

  • Ingress Gateway with TLS and mTLS
  • Security Aspects of Ingress Gateway
  • Troubleshooting Ingress Gateway

III. Peer Authentication

  • Activate mTLS for entire mesh
  • Co-existence of different workloads (with and without mTLS)
  • Troubleshooting mTLS

IV. Request Authentication

  • End-User Authentication
  • Prepare JWT and JWKS
  • JWT claim based routing

V. Authorization

  • AuthorizationPolicy
  • Establish default deny-all rule
  • Explicit deny of a request
  • Test new policies with dry run
  • Security Best Practices

VI. Request Authorization

  • JWT claim based authorization
  • JWT claim based routing

VII. Egress Gateway

  • Controlled access to external services
  • Troubleshooting Egress Gateway

VIII. Istiod Certificate

  • Istio’s Certificate Management


The slides and the code examples together with the Kubernetes/Istio scripts we will use are available to the participants.
session.workshopAttendeeInformationsEn:
Dear workshop participant,the technical requirements for the workshop are as follows:

On-site participants:
  • Laptop with an internet connection is required
  • Should have headphones with mic to collaborate with remote participants if needed.
  • Please think of a suitable socket adapter for your notebooks
Remote participants:
  • The workshop will take place exclusively in Zoom for remote participants. Communication will take place via Zoom Chat.
  • Audio (and video) setup to be able to actively participate.


Please have a look here to prepare for the Service Mesh Workshop:

https://hofmann-itconsulting.de/assets/servicemeshworkshop/TeilnehmerVorbereitungWorkshop.html#ambient-minikube


We wish you a successful workshop and look forward to seeing you!

Best regards,
Conference Team
session.name: Service Mesh Security Workshop with Istio Ambient: Manage mTLS, AuthN and AuthZ
session.details: In this workshop, participants will be shown the possibilities that a service mesh tool like Istio Ambient offers in terms of security. Istio Ambient enables a new service mesh architecture that completely eliminates sidecars. After a brief introduction to the service mesh, more and more security features are presented and implemented in each step.

session.workshopRequirements:
- Having a github account and basic programming skills such as knowing python, java and linux. 

- Having basic cloud and cybersecurity knowledge is a plus point.
session.longAbstract:
The workshop will be broken down into primarily 3 Phases where we will cover the following areas and parameters around Generative AI Security & Critical Infrastructure Security

Phase 1 : Setting the ground with a real-world example of a Mortgage Lending & Health Care

company who has challenges with Gen AI and want to overcome risks

● Getting Started with Generative AI Security along with its Model Lifecycle

● Gen AI Risks and consequences in HealthCare and Mortgage Industry

● Use cases of prompt injection and hallucination activities using trained dataset


Phase 2 : After analyzing the use case and the Gen AI lifecycle, it's time to list out the Cyber

controls as per the industry category and see their capabilities considering AI Data Governance

● Secure AI Data Governance, Data Security, Privacy & Trust

● Approach to Securing Generative AI Capabilities

● Key Areas to Consider for Gen AI Related Security Controls


Phase 3 : Recommendations sample with cyber controls mapped against its frameworks

followed by Secure Gen AI Adoption Roadmap

● Recommended Gen AI security controls mapped with NIST AI-Risk Management

Framework

● Secure Gen AI - Value based Roadmap

● Responsible AI Principles & Frameworks


Towards the end you will get an overall understanding of establishing a strategic data governance framework for AI capabilities and will be developing a comprehensive AI strategy including industry wide best practices, Governance, Risk, Compliance, Risks Mitigation techniques, Government Policies and Standards.

Best regards,
Conference Team
session.name: Confidence in AI Workshop- Securing Enterprise Generative AI Systems & Critical Infrastructure
session.details: As Generative AI becomes deeply embedded in enterprise and societal systems, the question is no longer “Can we build it?” but it's rather “Can we trust it? And “How we can secure it”? This strategizing and technical workshop explores how to establish confidence in AI—not just in terms of performance, but in security, privacy, transparency, and governance. We will unpack the unique security challenges and risks posed by GenAI, including adversarial prompts, model leaks, hallucination, and data misuse etc. With real-world examples and emerging best practices, the session outlines how organizations can implement security controls such as red teaming, model monitoring, usage policies, access control etc. using various AI frameworks such as NIST AI-RMF and ISO 42001 and map it against various stages of Gen AI lifecycle from model development to model monitoring. We’ll incorporate AI development with regulatory frameworks, from GDPR to the EU AI & India AI Act etc. and highlight how organizations can embed governance into AI lifecycle through automation and policy enforcement. Crucially, we’ll highlight the role of data governance & data security in building trustworthy AI from securing training data to ensuring regulatory compliance and ethical integrity. Attendees will leave with a strategic understanding of how to design GenAI systems with a forward-looking roadmap.

session.workshopRequirements:
Target Group:

  • Web developers who want to build secure applications.

  • Software and security architects who want to implement security concepts effectively.

  • IT experts who want to develop their skills in web security.

  • Security enthusiasts who want to understand attack and defense techniques.
session.longAbstract:
Day 1: Security Fundamentals and Attack Vectors (9:00 AM - 4:30 PM)


1. IT Security Foundations


  • CIA triad and security principles

  • Encryption: Symmetric vs. asymmetric

  • Hashing methods and their applications

  • Hands-on: Encryption tools in practice

2. Browser Security mechanism


  • Same Origin Policy and Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS)

  • Cookie security: httpOnly, Secure, SameSite attributes

  • Session management and secure token strategies

  • Lab: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing

3.  HTTP Security Header


  • Configure security-relevant HTTP headers

  • Properly implement Content Security Policy (CSP)

  • HSTS, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options

  • Lab: HTTP Security Header

4. Web Application Attacks Part 1


  • Intro into OWASP Top 10 2025

session.name: Web Security Bootcamp - Day 1
session.details: This intensive two-day hands-on workshop teaches you to effectively secure modern web applications. Experience firsthand how attacks work and develop concrete defense strategies. From OWASP Top 10 to OAuth2 and Content Security Policy – master current security concepts through realistic scenarios and cutting-edge tools.The workshop combines theoretical foundations with intensive hands-on exercises: identify vulnerabilities, implement security measures, and test your applications with professional security tools. After the camp, you'll be able to recognize vulnerabilities, develop secure APIs, and implement authentication with OAuth2.Perfect for web developers, software architects, and IT security experts who want to future-proof their applications against evolving threats.

session.workshopRequirements:
• A working knowledge of Git as a version control system and comfort with the command line is highly recommended.
  • Please bring your own laptop equipped with a web browser and git tools to fully engage in the practical exercises.
  • For those who prefer to use their own machine instead of a workshop cluster, please prepare Docker Desktop or another local Kubernetes setup.
session.longAbstract:
Day 1

1.  Getting a cluster

  • You will be provided with different options to get a cluster in order to participate in all Kubernetes practice labs
  • Every participant will have the option to use a web based workshop cluster which is especially suitable for participants with enterprise managed notebooks
  • A local cluster with minikube or Docker Desktop is a good way for revisiting the workshop labs later on
  • We will also look into various tools that make working with Kubernetes eaier

2. Accessing your cluster

  • Security is important, so no cluster can be accessed without authentication and authorization
  • How that is implemented in Kubernetes lays a good foundation to handle multiple clusters in parallel

3. Building application images

  • Kubernetes uses container images to provide workload for the cluster
  • You will build your own images using Docker and Dockerfiles
  • We will use these images in the cluster later on to show various important operational aspects
  • Images are distributed using container registries

4. Fundamental Kubernetes concepts

  • We will understand how Kubernetes is organized using namespaces
  • Our first workload will be a simple pod to avoid unnecessary complexity
  • Important elements of the architecture of Kubernetes like etcd, controller manager, scheduler, api server and kubelet will be visited in detail
  • We will learn how to interact with network applications inside Kubernes
  • ... and how to access them from outside the cluster
  • For diagnosis we will run interactive containers inside the cluster

5. Running your applications

  • Now it is time to run our own applications which is a good opportunity to quickly revisit the basics
  • We use the container image we built earlier and even scale it to multiple relicas which leads to the concept of replica sets
  • Using healthcheck probes we will ensure that our customers will only reach healthy instances

6. Using Kubernetes resources

  • Kubernetes is API centric and with our freshly acquired understanding of the architecture and building blocks we are well prepared to dive into the Kubernetes API in more detail
  • You will learn how to manage the configuration of your application using YAML manifests and how to work with them

session.name: 2 Days Kubernetes Bootcamp: Becoming a Kubernetes Master - From Clusters to Advanced Deployments - Day 1
session.details: This compact two-day workshop is designed to provide you with an in-depth understanding of Kubernetes. You will start with fundamental concepts and then progress to advanced topics such as volumes, ConfigMaps, Secrets, init-containers, Deployments, and persistence.Through hands-on labs, you will gain practical experience in deploying and managing applications in a Kubernetes cluster.By the end of the workshop, you will have a solid grasp of Kubernetes architecture and operations. This will enable you to deploy, access, and manage applications efficiently.You will be well-prepared to work with both cloud-based and on-premises Kubernetes solutions and engage in informed discussions about Kubernetes-based architectures with your peers.This workshop is ideal for developers who are already familiar with Docker or similar container technologies and are eager to dive into Kubernetes.

session.workshopRequirements:
Target Group:

Participants should already be working hands-on in roles that involve cloud-native infrastructure and DevOps principals such as:

  • Platform Engineers / SREs
  • Cloud Infrastructure Engineers
  • DevOps Engineers
  • Kubernetes Cluster Administrators
  • Backend Engineers with DevOps responsibilities
  • Technical Architects / Solution Architects
  • Security Engineers focused on cloud-native environments


Prerequisites

Familiarity with Kubernetes basics (Deployments, Services, ConfigMaps, Secrets).

Hands-on experience operating Kubernetes clusters, such as:

  • Managing workloads in staging or production
  • Using kubectl, YAML manifests, and GitOps workflows
  • Working knowledge of Git and basic shell scripting
session.longAbstract:
Agenda Day 1

101. Getting a Cluster

Every participant will be provided with a Kubernetes Cluster and webbased Desktop.

So you can participate even with your corporate Notebook.

You can also access your Cluster directly and use your local Environment. For that you need at least kubectl and git installed.

Practical cluster access and declarative configuration will be our entry point into this two day bootcamp. We will ramp up the learning curve by touching on control plane internals or GitOps automation tooling like ArgoCD or Flux.


102 Etcd: Storing K8s-objects in a filesystem

We are going to understand how K8s-objects are organized in etcd.

From that understanding RBAC and multi-tenant is a lot easier.


103. RoleBasesAccessControll (RBAC)

We generally focus on production-grade security by going through the following topics:

  • How does usermanagement (AuthN) work in Kubernetes?
  • AuthN with Credentials
  • AuthN with OIDC
  • What and why are there ServiceAccounts?
  • Managing privileges with RBAC
  • What are (Cluster)Roles and (Cluster)RoleBindings?
  • How to utilize them for minimal privileges?
  • Use of CLI-based tools to work with Roles and Bindings


104. NetworkPolicy and Topology Aware Routing

  • Get an overview about the Kubernetes-Network
  • What is Topology Aware Routing?
  • CNI and NetworkPolicy
  • Write NetworkPolicies (to protect your applications)
  • Use tools to debug networking issues


With these topics we will raise awareness about performance/scalability and take a look into intra-cluster traffic control.

session.longAbstract:
Day 2: Attacks on Web Application Defense Strategies and Modern Identity Management (9:00 AM - 4:30 PM)

1. ﻿Web Application Attacks Part 2

  • Cross-Site Scripting (XSS): Reflected, Stored, DOM-based

  • Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) and countermeasures

  • SQL injection and other injection attacks

  • DoS attacks and defense strategies

  • Lab Capture-the-Flag: Exploit vulnerabilities in test applications

2. Defense Strategies


  • Systematic protection against known attack vectors

  • Secure coding practices for modern frameworks

  • Input validation and output encoding

  • Hands-on: Secure a vulnerable application step by step

  • Manual vulnerability analysis: techniques and tools

  • Automated scanners: OWASP ZAP, Burp Suite, Nessus

  • Static Application Security Testing (SAST) vs. Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST)


3. OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect: flows and best practices


  • JWT tokens: security and correct implementation

  • OAuth2.1/OIDC Flows

  • Identity provider integration in modern web applications

  • Common Threats and Best Practices

  • Backend for Frontend Pattern

session.longAbstract:
Day 2

1.  Ingress

  • Many APIs and web applications are based on the HTTP protocol. With the Kubernetes ingress concept you will manage the access efficiently.
  • With these elements we look into running more complex applications or microbased services

2. Volumes and configuration

  • Kubernetes provides various ways to handle configuration and secret data
  • We will work with config maps, secrets and how they can be used for pods

3. Deployments

  • One concept with high abstraction level is the Kubernetes Deployment
  • We will use it to manage multiple versions of our application and to roll out updates without any downtime

4.  Persistence

  • We need to persist our state outside of a pod to preserve it in case of planned updates or even failures
  • We will lean how persistent volumes and persistent volume claims work
  • With storage classes we can provide different kinds of storage in a well defined manner

Depending on the time left we will discuss your use cases and questions to ensure that you have a solid understanding and are ready to start with Kubernetes for your projects.

session.longAbstract:
Agenda Day 2

201. Controller

  • What is the AdmissionController
  • Let's have a look at all the running Controllers in the cluster
  • Let's write a simple (shell-based) Controller
  • When to use Controller or Operators


202. Operator

  • Operators are so powerful in extending Kubernetes. Let's have a look at some examples.
  • Writing your own CRDs is to easy. Let's write them
  • Writing a Shell-based Controller (fitting RBAC included)
  • While writing Shell-based Operators and Controllers is nice let's have a look into kubebuilder
  • for writing golang-based Controllers and Operators

In these two final sessions we be going over the operator pattern and lifecycle management.


203. BYOT - Bring Your Own Topics

Dedicated space to discuss your questions and analyse cases that you have been dealing with. <3
